div.sent: To live a pure and sacred life Gautama Buddha advised His followers to abide by some rules and regulations set by Him.
These rules, if duly observed make human beings perfect and bring salvation from sufferings decaying the cravings.
Greed, hatred, violence and malice might be avoided.
Human beings can earn the qualities of tolerance, non-violence and self-control possessing kindness and compassion to all.
The world is full of sufferings.
Buddhism aims at salvation from all these sufferings following the rules and ways set by the Buddha.
These directives however, are known as Precepts.
Here follows an instance for realizing the meaning and significance of the Precepts : The cultivator grows crops in his field.
Before harvesting the field is well ploughed for cultivation.
Then he gets a good harvest.
The Precept is such a field.
If the field is not well cultivated, no desire is fulfilled.
Precept is the basic foundation of all religious practices.
We should concentrate our mind in Precept before all other religious performances.
Now it is clear that Precept is such a stage based on salvation from sufferings.
In a nutshell we can realize that Precept is the stair to attain Nibbana.
The Precepts have some stages and are to be observed step by step.
The first step is the Five Precepts.
Then follows the Eight and Ten Precepts.
But all of them are not applicable for all.
Five Precepts are compulsory to be observed by the lay-devotees.
Eight Precepts are also for the lay Buddhists.
The Samaneras and Bhikkhus have to follow the Ten Precepts regularly.
We have learnt about Five Precepts previously.
Now let us discuss about the Eight Precepts.
The Eight Precepts is the second step including Five Precepts and three more Precepts.
Five Precepts may commonly be observed in daily life.
But the Eight Precepts are not so easy to the lay people to observe regularly.
They are observed in some particular days.
The observing days of the Eight Precepts are the new moon, the eighth day of every lunar fortnight and the full moon.
Those who observe the Eight Precepts have to starve in those days.
The observing days of the Eight Precepts are called the Uposatha days or the days of fasting and the observers are known as Uposathikas.
There are some rules to accept the Uposatha Silas i.e.
On the Uposatha day the observers put on clean cloths and go to the monastery with flowers and offering materials.
They put all that brought by them before the image of the Buddha and take part in the prayer before the Buddha.
Thereafter they take seats in front of the monks with folded hands for prayer.
They pay their tribute to the Triple- gems and pray for Eight Precepts from the monk.
Venerable oh monk, pay attention please, I do pray for Uposathasilam of Eight fold virtues with refuge to the Triple-gems.
Please, offer me the Precepts.
A second time, venerable oh monk, I do pray for Uposathasilam of Eightfold , virtues with refuge to the Triple-gems.
Please offer me the-Precepts.
A third time, venerable oh monk, I do pray for Uposathasilam of Eightfold virtues with refuge to the Triple-gems.
Please offer me the Precepts.
To offer Precepts, the Bhikkhu will utter yamaham vadami tam vadetha i.e. follow me what I say.
The lay devotee then say, Ama bhante, i.e. yes, I follow.
With this consent the Bhikkhu will start offering the Precepts.
The followers will recite them accordingly with right and distinct pronunciation.
I undertake the Precept to abstain from killing.
I undertake the Precept to abstain from stealing.
I undertake the Precept to abstain from sexual misconduct.
I undertake the Precept to abstain from telling lies.
I undertake the Precept to abstain from taking intoxicants.
I undertake the Precept to abstain from having meals in the afternoon.
I undertake the Precept to abstain from enjoying dances, songs and music, applying cosmetics and putting on valuable ornaments.
I undertake the Precept to abstain from lying on valuable high seats.
Do follow the Uposathasilam (Eight Precepts) of Eight-fold virtues carefully.
The lay devotee should say, Ama bhante, i.e. yes, I follow.
Now the Bhikkhu will recite a few Sutras for the welfare of the laity.
Nothing should be taken thereafter excepting drinks only.
We should keep it in mind that fasting is not enough.
Each and every Precept should be followed properly with great care.
It is rather difficult to observe the Eight Precepts staying with the family members.
So they should stay at the monastery listening to the ritual advice of the monks.
Every Uposathika of course, can take part on religious discussions and recitation from the holy Tripitaka.
The Uposathika must refrain from any kind of activities that hamper the practice of the Eight Precepts.
The Uposathikas have to observe some duties necessary for them are as follows:
The Uposathika should neither harm nor cause to harm anybody.
They should neither oppress nor cause to oppress the other beings or animals.
They should neither outrage nor cause to outrage the others.
They should not misbehave with others.
They should not foster malice for the prosperity and appreciation of others.
They should never tell lies.
They should avoid the discussion on family affairs.
They should listen to the religious discussions attentively.
They should take part on religious discussions.
They should keep them away from household affairs.
They should have no feelings of sensitivity.
They should exercise control in walking, visualizing and speaking.
Life is the source of a living being.
As I have the affection to life, so have it to all living beings.
It is a great sin to destroy the life of others.
Therefore, we should have to abstain from killing the animals larger or smaller in size, ferocious or inoffensive.
Nobody should be encouraged for killing.
We should always be kind to all living beings and wish their happiness.
Thus we undertake Precept of non-violence.
To take anything without the consent of the owner is stealing.
It is a great sin to take away anything, which is not given.
We should neither do such a sinful act nor encourage others to do so.
Thus we undertake the teaching of the Precept that we should not wish the loss or cause to loss of others.
Refraining from sexual desire is known as Brahmacariya.
So should we abstain from such sexual desire showing respect to the women-folk.
We should never cast any evil look upon anybody nor insist others on doing so thus we undertake the teaching of this Precept.
We should never tell lies even for jokes.
Rude behaviour with others should be avoided.
Nobody should be encouraged to speak ill of others.
This is the teaching of the Precept that we undertake.
We should refrain from taking alcohols made of rice and cakes and five kinds of wine made of fruit juice along with arrak, ganja etc.
Even we should never encourage anybody to take them.
This is the teaching of this Precept.
Having meals after 12 A.M. is called supper.
The Uposathikas cannot have their meals from 12 A.M. till the next sunrise.
Other than hard food milk, barley, tea mixed with milk and fruits are also prohibited to take.
They are only allowed to drink water and some other light drinks.
So we undertake the teaching of this Precept to abstain from having the supper.
To witness dances and hearing the songs even enjoying ox fighting, wrestling and the magic show are strictly prohibited for the Uposathikas (lay devotees).
So should we undertake the Precept of this Precept to abstain from using cosmetics and decorating with costly dresses.
I do undertake the teaching of the Precept of abstaining from lying on luxurious and high bed-stead's.
There are so many good-effects of observing the Eight Precepts (Uposatha silas).
The restless mind becomes peaceful.
It dispels committing crimes and mental anxieties.
The mind is purified with lot of virtues concentrating in truth.
It leads us to be kind- hearted to all living-beings developing the power of tolerance and self control.
Greed, ill desires and the tendency of evil doings are reduced.
Violence and mental disposition are also removed by practicing Uposathasilam (the Eight Precepts).
Human being is controlled by habit.
Fasting for four days a month is possible.
That is, man can practice to live a holy life at least for these four days.
Gradually the power of fasting enables man to live an honest life for eight days, sixteen days, a month even a year.
In this way, everybody becomes honest and virtuous.
The honest habit thus will be a permanent natural quality.
By no means other person can allure the devotee to become dishonest once again.
The practice of the Eight Precepts brings more moral effects to the observer.
Those who practice the Eight Precepts, always remain fearless, live a disciplined life, become happy forever and can engage themselves in meditation without anxiety.
The contemplation up rises the performer to Samadhi for attaining wisdom.
Morality, wisdom and concentration in a body is the first step to get rid of sufferings.
Thus the performer of the Eight Precepts can feel the happiness of Nibbana dedicating himself to the path of Dhamma.
Uposatha Silas (the Eight Precepts) possess numerous qualities.
The qualities of the sun and the moon are uncountable.
The earth is meaningless in absence of the sun and the moon.
Where as the practice of the Uposatha Silas is much more effective than their qualities.
This practice is further more valuable than the treasures that lie at the bottom of the sea.
The smell of the Eight Precepts is much sweeter than the smell of the flowers and the musk of the deer.
The sweet smell of both the wind and the musk flows towards the direction of the wind.
On the other hand, the sweet smell of the Precepts flows in all directions.
The worldly fragrance is transitory but the fragrance of the Precepts is everlasting.
Once the Buddha described an incident of His previous life to show the merits of the Eight Precepts.
The story is as follows: Once Bodhisattva was born in a poor family.
At that time, an honest richman lived at Rajagriha.
He was as wealthy as kind.
He had much feeling for the sufferings of others.
He always tried his best to set them free from sorrows and sufferings.
All the members of his family used to observe Five and Eight Precepts.
So his family was well known as the holy family.
Bodhisattva at that time had to work in others house for his livelihood.
Once he went to the richman for job.
The master of the house said to him, All the members of my family along with the man and maid servants observe the Uposatha Silas.
If you can observe it you will get a job.
Bodhisattva had been virtuous enough from previous to the recent life.
How could he deny the proposal who had the influence of the Precepts?
He became cheerful to hear the name of Precepts and said, Yes my master, I must do so.
Bodhisattva engaged himself in the job and performed his duties diligently.
He always thought of his master to satisfy him.
It was the Uposatha day.
But Bodhisattva was not aware of it.
He went to do his duty early in the morning.
Meanwhile the master took Uposathasilam along with all the members of his family including the man and maid servants.
In the evening all of them were absorbed in meditation.
In the meantime, Bodhisattva came, but found none in the house.
The house was quite silent.
He was unfed for the whole day.
He felt too much, hungry.
A maid servant saw him and brought food to him.
What is the reason behind it?
He wanted to know the fact from the maid servant.
She said, It. is Uposatha day to day.
Everybody is fasting to observe Precepts.
On hearing this his hunger vanished.
He too thought of observing the Precepts.
He stood up without having meals.
He went to the master and said, Sir, I am sorry I did not know that to-day is the day of fasting.
So I could not observe it in the morning.
Can I observe the day since now?
The master said, The result will be half if you observe it for half a day.
It is enough- said, Bodhisattva and he began to observe the Precepts for the rest of the time by fasting.
He became tired and hungry by doing hard labour all day long.
Yet he determined to observe Uposatha.
As the night fell deep Bodhisattva felt pain in his stomach.
The pain began to increase gradually.
He groaned and groaned with unbearable pain.
The master heard it and he came with ghee, butter and molasses mixed with honey.
He gave all these to Bodhisattva, asked him to take them.
But he took none and said, Oh my master, let my life be gone, yet I shall not break the Uposatha.
In the-early morning the king of Beneras went out for a morning walk.
He was passing near the house of the rich-man.
Bodhisattva saw a handsome personality standing a bit away from him.
He could recognise the king and his heart was full of joy.
He thought, Were I king in my next life.
He died as soon as he thought it.
The craving that created just at the moment of death was fulfilled in the next life.
After death Bodhisattva was born as the prince of Beneras and was named as Udaya kumara.
From this tale of Bodhisattva, we come to realize the good effects of the Uposatha.
This is the real teaching of the Buddha.
The Buddha proclaimed that everybody might be great in this way.
So we should remember this noble teaching of the Buddha throughout our life.
